April 17, 2005: Fiction
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a
curator at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to
the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.
REVENGE OF THE SITH, by Matthew Stover. (Lucas/Del Rey/Ballantine, $25.95.)
A new "Star Wars" novel, featuring Anakin Skywalker and Obi-Wan Kenobi.
YA-YAS IN BLOOM, by Rebecca Wells. (HarperCollins, $24.95.) The further
adventures of members of the Ya-Ya sisterhood.
HONEYMOON, by James Patterson and Howard Roughan. (Little, Brown,
$27.95.) An F.B.I. agent who is investigating a beautiful and mysterious woman
finds himself becoming obsessed with her.
SATURDAY, by Ian McEwan. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $26.) A day in the life of
a successful London neurosurgeon, troubled by 9/11 and the impending war in
Iraq, who comes face to face with senseless violence.
THE RISING, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $25.99.) The Prince
of Darkness chooses a Romanian woman to be the mother of the Antichrist.
THE BROKER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) The C.I.A. arranges a
presidential pardon for a power broker who may know crucial secrets, laying a trap
for the foreign intelligence service that wants him dead.
WITH NO ONE AS WITNESS, by Elizabeth George. (HarperCollins, $26.95.)
Detective Inspector Thomas Lynley and his colleagues hunt for a serial killer.
IMPOSSIBLE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $27.) A romance blossoms between
the owner of a Parisian art gallery and a bohemian painter.
THE SERPENT ON THE CROWN, by Elizabeth Peters. (Morrow, $25.95.) Having
returned to Egypt in 1922, the archaeologist Amelia Peabody and her family
become embroiled in treachery and intrigue.
THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.)
An old man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that
all will be explained to him in the afterlife.
EXTREMELY LOUD AND INCREDIBLY CLOSE, by Jonathan Safran Foer.
(Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) A 9-year-old boy searches New York City for the lock
that fits a key belonging to his father, who died on Sept. 11.
PREP, by Curtis Sittenfeld. (Random House, $21.95.) A scholarship student from
South Bend, Ind., encounters a world of privilege when she attends an expensive
boarding school in Massachusetts.
HARD TRUTH, by Nevada Barr. (Putnam, $24.95.) The national park ranger Anna
April 17, 2005
Non-Fiction
BLINK, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The author of "The Tipping
Point" explores the importance of hunch and instinct to the workings of the mind.
A DEADLY GAME, by Catherine Crier with Cole Thompson.
(ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $27.95.) A former judge and current Court TV analyst
looks at the Scott Peterson case.
ON BULL----, by Harry G. Frankfurt. (Princeton University, $9.95.) A philosopher
attempts a theoretical understanding of a "vast and amorphous" phenomenon.
CONSPIRACY OF FOOLS, by Kurt Eichenwald. (Broadway, $26.) The
spectacular rise and fall of Enron, as reported by a correspondent for The New
York Times.
BLOOD BROTHER, by Anne Bird. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $25.95.) The
long-lost half sister of Scott Peterson explains why she is convinced he is guilty of
murder.
AMERICA (THE BOOK), by Jon Stewart, Ben Karlin and David Javerbaum.
(Warner, $24.95.) "The Daily Show" offers a lavishly illustrated parody of a civics
textbook.
PLAN B, by Anne Lamott. (Riverhead, $24.95.) The author of "Traveling Mercies"
meditates on personal and political matters and on the spiritual life.
MEN IN BLACK, by Mark R. Levin. (Regnery, $27.95.) A lawyer and conservative
commentator enumerates ways in which "the Supreme Court is destroying
America."
COLLAPSE, by Jared Diamond. (Viking, $29.95.) A historical investigation, by the
author of "Guns, Germs, and Steel," into why some societies succeed while others
fail.
GOD'S POLITICS, by Jim Wallis. (HarperSanFrancisco, $24.95.) An evangelical
Christian argues that Democrats must "take back the faith" and not allow
conservative Republicans to hijack the Bible.
JUICED, by Jose Canseco. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $25.95.) The former
slugger talks about his life in baseball and, especially, his use of steroids.
THREE NIGHTS IN AUGUST, by Buzz Bissinger. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) A three-
game series in 2003 between the Cubs and the Cardinals, as seen through the
eyes of Tony La Russa, the St. Louis manager.
THE GLASS CASTLE, by Jeannette Walls. (Scribner, $25.) The author, a
contributor to MSNBC.com, recalls a bizarre childhood during which she and her
siblings were constantly being moved from one bleak place to another.
